Recommended Reason: Site of 2019/2020 Bronze Age gold treasure discovery now displayed in Natural History Museum Vienna
Supporting Evidence: 5-piece gold treasure including gold bowl and jewelry fragments discovered during ÖBB construction work, dating to Bronze Age

Recommended Reason: Gallery 16 underground tunnel network used for Operation Bernhard Nazi counterfeit operation with potential hidden caches
Supporting Evidence: Former Nazi underground facility where banknote presses were stored, part of extensive Alpine tunnel system for hiding valuables

Recommended Reason: Nazi dumping site for Operation Bernhard counterfeit notes and potentially other wartime treasures
Supporting Evidence: Millions in forged banknotes were dumped here, and the lake remains largely unexplored due to its depth and dangerous conditions

Recommended Reason: Part of planned Nazi National Redoubt with multiple tunnel systems and treasure caches hidden in mountains
Supporting Evidence: Extensive tunnel networks were built for hiding gold, art, and valuables from advancing Allied forces, many remain unexplored

Recommended Reason: Near the Celtic gold treasure of Manching, one of the most important finds in German-speaking countries
Supporting Evidence: Celtic settlements and trade routes extended across this border region, with potential for undiscovered hoards

Recommended Reason: Center of ancient Hallstatt culture with extensive Iron Age and Bronze Age settlements and burial sites
Supporting Evidence: Archaeological site of the Hallstatt culture with rich burial traditions and metalworking, ongoing excavations reveal artifacts

Recommended Reason: Historic Habsburg capital with Roman foundations and medieval hoards frequently discovered during construction
Supporting Evidence: Major European capital with continuous occupation since Roman times, recent archaeological finds during construction projects

Recommended Reason: Major Roman city and legionary fortress, ongoing excavations revealing significant artifacts and potential hoards
Supporting Evidence: One of the most important Roman archaeological sites in Austria, with amphitheater, civilian city, and military camp remains
